column4: Gea: I prefixed the echo > with a sudo. Is that not enough to become root?
that wouldn't work .. try.   echo blah | sudo tee /path/to/file
or tee -a  if you want to append to the file
sudo echo blah > file  # will fail miserably
see my last post to you.
Doing the tee :)
the file permissions are 444 - is it OK to change them to 644
well, that depends on what you want the file to do
3-year old thinkpad r-52
well, 444 does fine if all you want is to be able to read from the file
keep 444 if all you are doing is changing something inside the file.
root can write to any file .. irrespective of permissions
Did that - (| sudo tee ) file contents did not change
paste your exact command here.
echo ondemand | sudo tee scaling_governor
and the output of pwd?
/sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq
hmm, not sure why this is
try removing the file before attempting this.
ok, and?
I mean, err, can I remove a file from /sys, /proc etc.?
could explain why  echo blah > file  is unsuccessful
For that the recco method is to echo "ondemand" into the /sys file
is my intention clear - have i explained my problem?
